Pros: Good balance of work and life
Cons: Market challenging based upon technology

Review Title: Not a difficult job. Poor training, Upper management is out of touch
Pros: There is a lot of flexibility for time and everyone in the division is helpful. The job isn't difficult. Direct managers are all really good people. Good job for someone with minimal experience.
Cons: Upper/Senior management are very out of touch with what our job really is and what it takes to be successful. The markets we sell in are totally diluted (some of which is KM's fault). You will be competing against your own machines at a cheaper price by 3rd party re-sellers. High stress times = crazy amounts of micro management. No room for career growth. Service sucks too.

Pros: Benefits are good, 401k, health, dental, vision
Cons: No cons at this time

Pros: The organization offers a stable work environment with advanced sales training and quality products to sell

Review Title: Good people and place to start a career.
Pros: Name recognition and products are well received. Have many other products and services to offer from the IT business for SMB customers.
Cons: Maybe to many offerings to get a real focus on segments.

Pros: Long term employees is a plus.
Cons: Outdated systems and outdated policy.

Pros: While customers come first, KMBS is very employee-centric with excellent opportunities for growth. Great company culture and benefits, specially with PTO (15 PTO days + sick). I had an outstanding onboarding experience and love working with my team.
Cons: In my experience, the starting salary was lower than the market value for my position. Recruiting process was lengthy and not always clear.

Review Title: Used to be a great place to work now it is now
Pros: flexible, great presidents club trips
Cons: service manager fights with your customers so you lose deals, won't even give you a base salary raise, I made less every year since I hit presidents club and barley made $100,000 the year I did. After I left, they wanted to hire me back and would give me a raise but when I asked for one before I left, I was told no. I got overpaid commission and didn't realize it since they were doing advances on commission since delivery time was 6-9 months. They withheld my commission 4 months later with 0 notice. I had to door dash every day after work to make up for it and started losing my hair from stress. Asked for a raise and no one cared!

Review Title: OKC Office needs a lot of work
Pros: very flexible sales job now
Cons: no one in office knows what's going on.

Pros: Travel, work with minimal supervision
Cons: not compensated good enough for fairly tasked work

Pros: The on-boarding experience has been pleasant. Konica Minolta has a structured approach to the on-boarding process.
Cons: The on-boarding process is new and there are some minor tweaks that need to be addressed.

Pros: manage control inventory and picking
Cons: challenge to learn new objectives

Pros: Great culture and room for growth!
Cons: No downsides to speak of.

Pros: Good pay and benefits, great people.
Cons: Reps not providing proper documents on time.

Pros: Good product, nice management, friendly team.
Cons: Unable to deliver. Due to poor logistics, accountability, and clarity on orders placed - our operations and logistics teams frequently rely on feedback from customers to let us know something was not completed. They will not reach out to schedule. They will wait until the customer is questioning what's going on enough to reach out and ask what happened. They are ready and able to take customer money, but drag their feet to deliver an actual product or service as contractually obligated.

Pros: The fancy coffee machine sometimes works and it's free.
Cons: This company will hold you back in your career. Not generous with pay, bonuses do not exist, workloads have only gone up in my time here, and certain departments are treated dramatically different from others. You can often get away with not working for a very long time before being fired because there are minimal consequences for low performers and no reward for high performers.

Pros:

Too many solutions in search of a problem

Pros:
They will get your foot in the door as a tech 
Money is decent for people getting by not for a family
Cons:
They never give raises 
They never give promotions 
They care only in numbers 
They want you to be in and out within a hour 
They will put 20 plus calls on a screen 
They don't want you to next day anything due to cost and if you do you gotta ask a manager and have them agree while at customer site
Even being a tech for 8 years never once received a promotion after doing office equipment and production equipment
You use your own vehicles so get ready for ware and tare on your personal stuff and they don't pay for tires, maintenance on your vehicle and you have to do it on your own time not company time and they expect you to be on site at 8 am no matter the time you leave in the morning and your not paid going to the account and they mark your miles during company time and by end of day your mileage doesn't count going home. 
The insurance is expensive and not that great Cigna is what they use
They will throw you to the wolves
Low salary with little raises if any 
They don't care about the techs and see them to be replaced with ease
They care more about there parts then your life 
My vehicle was stolen and a month later was suspended for losing there parts
They will throw people's inventory in yours and expect you to fix it

Pros: Great sales floor coworkers are awesome, good PTO and holiday schedule

Review Title: Named Account Executive- lacking development for mid market reps
Pros: Portfolio is large. KM prides themselves in being a total “business solution” provider. With nationwide offices. Hardware is the bread and butter but has a lot to offer in the SAAS, managed IT portfolio, cyber security, security cameras.
Cons: Service was not good. Technicians are not paid enough and the reputation and sales suffer. Post sales IT sales was terrible.

Pros: Work life balance is great especially if you have a kid or in school.
Cons: The pay for all of the job responsibilities in the administration team is nowhere near enough to support a single person household. It can be difficult to work cohesively with sales if you’re a team player due to the variety of personalities.

Review Title: Good entry level job, but not a career.
Pros:
There are many entry-level positions at Konica Minolta and the company is willing to take a chance on individuals who lack experience. The training was decent and managers are fine with letting you learn at your own pace. Coworkers are more than willing to lend a helping hand and help fellow staff members get up to speed.

The work environment is generally comfortable and there is a cafeteria on site. The company also hosts lots of events and activities for staff, especially during the holidays.

Their corporate roles are good for entry-level folks looking to gain some exposure to, and experience in the corporate world.
Cons:
The biggest con at this company is lack of flexibility and WFH options. During the pandemic everyone worked from home. Then they implemented a hybrid policy that allowed for 2 days WFH. Then they only allowed one day a week as WFH. The 2 days WFH seemed reasonable, and lowering WFH to one day a week seemed unwarranted. They implemented some new stuff to make up for it, but what is the point? Why not just let us WFH at least 2 days a week? Most of the jobs at Ramsey HQ can be done completely remotely to begin with. Seems completely unnecessary. From what I understand, folks in upper management are allowed to work completely remotely. Rules for thee, but not for me. 

In addition, there is a high degree of micromanaging here. Seems that most managers do not care about quality of work. The only thing that managers seem to care about is if you are sitting at your desk like a good worker bee. Don't be away from your desk too often or 5 minutes late because someone will tattle on you. Also, don't ask for too many days off or your manager might get annoyed. A lot of long-time employees will be rude, disrespectful, and bossy. Some of the disrespect you can experience is truly shocking. But it seems like people just put up with it because KM is the only place they have ever known and they are afraid to leave.

Pros: Great ongoing training, flexibility, Great leadership
Cons: Competitive Industry that at times feels commoditized, when competing against KM dealers in the same market

Pros: Good people good hours when I was there
Cons: The ceiling there is not high

Pros: Great work life balance, friendly people, good leadership, learned a lot.
Cons: A lot of responsibilities for the pay, disorganization within admin, if you don't have a good boss or good accounts you will hate this job, great job if you are straight out of college and want a start in sales

Pros: I have enjoyed a career with Konica Minolta by working hard and being rewarded for it. The company has done a great job to provide incentives to learn, opportunities to take on new projects and business plans. My immediate manager has provided great support and guidance to help me advance my career. The products we support, the everyday people I interact with are great to work with. In my role, I interact with a large cross section of the company from sales, service, administration, logistics, finance, warehouse teams and everyone is generally friendly and easy to work with.
Cons: Providing a more clear growth path to help advance in position, while recognizing the challenges we face by being more lean in headcount. Sometimes it takes time to get the right IT tools in place to support what we do, but no company is perfect and the continuous effort to make things better is noticed.

Pros: Great people and compensation for the work.

Review Title: Dying Industry with Old School Thinking
Pros: Decent base, autonomy for some, uncapped commissions if you get lucky.
Cons: Ridiculous quotas. A rep in NYC has the same quota as a rep in Orlando, FL. Territories are completely disjointed, starting, yours will likely get you 25% of your quota (they'll promise 70%) if you are lucky. Angry customers, difficult administration and logistics, lots of busy work in CRM and micro-management under some managers. Print is a dying industry, and this company is trying to pivot to software and solutions, perhaps too late. They use third parties for a lot of their solutions and are usually more expensive than competitors on top of being viewed as a legacy copier company.

Review Title: Old school but Japanese leadership keeps a steady hand
Pros: - Japanese style leadership; no frills; just keep working; lifetime employment - Recent peer shoutout system with monetary rewards - High quality healthcare, 401k, etc with robust benefits - Very good DEI and LGBTQ initiatives/employee groups
Cons: - US managers can be old school/cliquey

Pros: Depending on the position hours can be flexible and most managers don't micromanage, however it's important that productivity be positive and consistent. There's a chance for advancement but it typically involves lots of travel.
Cons: KMBS has a tendency to make drastic changes that upend an entire departments, a change in job title, but same role, can sometimes lead to having to interview for a job you're already doing and like many other corporations there's an abundance of management that doesn't feel entirely warranted.

Pros: Exciting time to join the company. In the midst of transforming the business from a Multi-Function Printer product company to a digital solutions provider that expands printing capabilities to encompass intelligent information management, managed print production, IT services, cybersecurity, and more. You need to be comfortable with and energized by change. Friendly, dedicated employees that have the best interests of the business at heart.
Cons: Progress is never a straight, smooth road. There are unexpected challenges or obstacles to progress, because when you are a company of 150 years, there are always legacy systems and processes. The company and employees are interested in addressing these areas. If you are willing to take ownership and drive change, you can have a great impact.

Pros: Great products, great people, and management.
Cons: Horrific, antiquated tech stack (besides Google Workspace). PLEASE invest in Salesforce (vs. the clunky and super frustrating SAP CRM that is currently in place). Very time consuming and frustrating to use in addition to a lack of an accurate pricing tool and proposal configuration tool. Are we really still using Excel spreadsheets in 2023? Why?

Pros: Most colleagues are pleasant. That's it, really.
Cons:
No promotional potential. Definition of a dead-end job. Awful compensation. An employee actually warned me during my first week to "make sure they pay me." In 3 years, I've only received a single 1% raise, and the same for my coworker. No cost-of-living increases; in doing the math on the US Fed BLS. website, I've lost over $7k since starting here due to inflation alone. I was even rated as "exceeding expectations" one year and still received nothing. Company constantly tries to find ways to cut costs while charging customers more, but never passes any of the increased profits down the line. Old fashioned "on-site" culture.

Dying industry--printing. Good luck 10 years from now. Contracts lost frequently due to most companies going 100% remote.

Come here only if you have a plan to leave and need a stopping point, and definitely don't come if you'd be working in the "lower ranks" such as warehouse, etc. They barely recognize you're human and will treat you as if you're a general laborer for the rest of the company and assign you tasks unrelated to your actual job.

Pros: Decent Salary good people, high pressure
Cons: No career advancement , high pressure

Review Title: Transforming into a new image is never easy....but it is rewarding to see progress
Pros:
Exciting time in the company and industry as Konica Minolta drives digital transformation internally and for customers. 
If you like to build new capabilities, spearhead new initiatives, and be challenged to learn new skills every day, then this is a great time to be part of Konica Minolta.
The company culture is broadening and there is a large focus on inclusion globally. 
Truly care about people and are evolving to be more responsive to employees' career development needs and goals.
Cons:
Change is hard....it means getting out of your comfort zone. It means there are people who are unhappy, stressed, and not bought-in. However, the executive leadership has been as transparent as possible about the direction the company is going. Regular town halls by the CEO and executive leadership team has been outlining the strategies for employees.
Nothing is perfect and there are lots of employee initiatives that are in the works, but not yet delivered. The future is bright, but navigating.

Review Title: Requiring Delivery Drivers to become install technicians was not smart
Pros: Nothing! Everything was absolutely horrible working at that job.
Cons: Nothing. Money is extremely low. Especially for delivery drivers. If you look at the total scenario of the job as a delivery driver you will be doing working for Konica Minolta. If you strictly want to do delivery, do not sign up for this job as a delivery driver for Konica Minolta.
